Text processing¶

centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.combine_sentiment_scores(positive_count, negative_count)[source]¶

Combines two sentiment scores into a single score.

Parameters:

  • positive_count (int) – Positive sentiment count.

  • negative_count (int) – Negative sentiment count.

Returns:

Combined sentiment score. Returns 0.0 if both counts are zero.

Return type:

float

Example

>>> combine_sentiment_scores(5, 3)
0.25
>>> combine_sentiment_scores(0, 0)
0.0
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.expand_contractions(text)[source]¶

Expands contractions in the input text based on a contraction dictionary.

Parameters:

text (str) – The input text containing contractions.

Returns:

Text with expanded contractions.

Return type:

str

Example

>>> contraction_map = {"can't": "cannot", "I'm": "I am"}
>>> expand_contractions("I can't go.")
'I cannot go.'
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.generate_ngrams(input_list, n)[source]¶

Generates n-grams from a list of tokens.

Parameters:

  • input_list (List[str]) – List of tokens.

  • n (int) – The number of tokens in each n-gram.

Yields:

Iterator[Tuple[str, …]] – An iterator over n-grams as tuples.

Return type:

Iterator[Tuple[str, ...]]

Example

>>> list(generate_ngrams(['I', 'love', 'coding'], 2))
[('I', 'love'), ('love', 'coding')]
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.load_content_from_txt(file_path)[source]¶

Reads the entire content of a text file from the given file path.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – The path to the text file.

Returns:

The content of the text file.

Return type:

str

Raises:

FilesNotLoadedException – If the file is not found at the given path.

Example

>>> content = load_content_from_txt("data/sample.txt")
>>> print(content)
'This is a sample text file.'
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.load_set_from_txt(file_path, is_lower=True)[source]¶

Reads the content of a text file and returns it as a set of lines.

Parameters:

  • file_path (str) – The path to the text file.

  • is_lower (bool, optional) – If True, converts the content to lowercase. Defaults to True.

Returns:

A set of lines from the text file.

Return type:

set

Raises:

FilesNotLoadedException – If there is an error reading the file.

Example

>>> word_set = load_set_from_txt("data/positive_words.txt")
>>> print(word_set)
{'happy', 'joyful', 'delighted'}
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.load_syllable_counts(file_path)[source]¶

Reads a file containing words and their syllable counts, and returns a dictionary.

Parameters:

file_path (str) – The path to the text file.

Returns:

A dictionary where keys are words and values are their syllable counts.

Return type:

Dict[str, int]

Raises:

FilesNotLoadedException – If the file is not found or has an invalid format.

Example

>>> syllables = load_syllable_counts("data/syllable_counts.txt")
>>> syllables['beautiful']
3
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.tokenize_text(text, spacy_tokenizer)[source]¶

Tokenizes the text and performs lemmatization, excluding stop words.

Parameters:

  • text (str) – The input text to tokenize.

  • spacy_tokenizer (spacy.Language) – Initialized SpaCy tokenizer.

Returns:

A list of lemmatized and filtered words.

Return type:

List[str]

Example

>>> nlp = spacy.load("en_core_web_sm")
>>> tokenize_text("I am loving the new features!", nlp)
['love', 'new', 'feature']
centralized_nlp_package.text_processing.text_utils.validate_and_format_text(text_input)[source]¶

Validates and formats the input text by ensuring it’s a non-empty string. If the input is a list of strings, joins them into a single string.

Parameters:

text_input (Optional[Union[str, List[str]]]) – The input text or list of texts to validate.

Returns:

Joined and stripped text if valid, else None.

Return type:

Optional[str]

Example

>>> validate_and_format_text("  Hello World!  ")
'Hello World!'
>>> validate_and_format_text(["Hello", "World"])
'Hello World'
>>> validate_and_format_text([])
None
